page.title: 03A TYPICAL FARM
page.content: The North Devon farms tend to concentrate on milk production as a general rule. The farms usually have between fifty and a hundred friesan cows. Many of the farmers also keep some sheep and all grow grass for silage and hay. Some also grow some grain crops for feed ,the straw being used for winter bedding. A few farmers have started growing fodder beet to supplement winter feeding. The milk produced goes to the creamery in Torrington where it is made into butter and cheese. Mr Pickard sells some of Mr. Lang's milk direct to the people of Parkham. The farmers use the local markets at Holsworthy and Bideford to sell and buy their stock though some is sent direct to the abattoir at Torrington.
